These protections apply in any city in Solano County that doesn't have its own ordinance, as well as in unincorporated Solano County. It lasts for 90 days after the California state of emergency ends (currently 5/31/2020).

Tenants do NOT have to show that their inability to pay was related to COVID-19; the county will assume that everyone is affected. If a landlord wants to argue otherwise, the burden is on the landlord to show that the tenant's circumstances are not related to the pandemic.

Tenants also have the right to break any lease with 30 days' notice, without penalties, as long as the reason is related to the pandemic (e.g., they lost their job or they need to care for relatives.)

Landlords who issue notices demanding rent or late fees must include must include information about these protections; see the ordinance for the exact requirement.

In some locations, however, circuit courts have specified that evictions will proceed, in some cases noting that appearances should occur by telephone. Under the Berkeley COVID-19 Emergency Response Ordinance, landlords cannot evict or attempt to evict a commercial or residential occupant for: Nonpayment of rent, where the occupant demonstrates nonpayment is due to the Coronavirus, the Coronavirus state of emergency, or after complying with a government Coronavirus precaution; or,
No-fault evictions of a residential tenant, except when necessary for the health and safety of tenants, neighbors, or the landlord. To gain these critical tenant protections, Berkeley tenants who suffer Coronavirus-related income disruption must, in writing, notify their landlords of their income disruption, and resultant inability to pay rent. Further, the tenant must attach documentation of their income disruption or COVID-19 out-of-pocket medical expense, such as a medical bill, paystubs, or letter from an employer indicating that the tenant has suffered reduced hours or lost wages due to the Coronavirus.  Where a landlord knows that a tenant cannot pay all or some of their rent due to the Coronavirus, the Berkeley COVID-19 Emergency Response Ordinance also prohibits landlords from serving notices to pay rent or quit, initiating a related eviction action in court, or prosecuting said eviction action. After the Coronavirus state of emergency ceases, a landlord has the right to collect unpaid rent; However, the landlord may not charge or collect a late fee for the unpaid rent
